ratings.question_text: How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: This class is very ambiguous and I don't think I really learned much of anything. Mendhlson came to Gillingham's Economics class in the fall and I don't think I learned more in the entire semester than I did in the two days he came to Gillingham's class. Kind of a waste of time.
N/A

The concepts taught in the course are interesting, engaging, and useful, but we didn't really explore them to the extent that a 3 credit course should warrant. Professor M never used the entire time (1-4, Mondays) to lecture, and he was often repeating himself- useful in drilling in the ideas, but I really wanted more information about each topic. Professor M is a otherwise a fantastic lecturer, and I would have appreciated more time listening to him talk - more examples, more discussion, etc. So much of it was overview. The pieces where he goes into the math behind the calculations was so surface, and we didn't need to know it for the exam - he should either fully explain it or not bother with formulas at all.
TA is very responsive. TA session is very helpful.
Professor Mendelsohn is great.
The ability to create your own project.
valuation methods are very useful
The readings do a great job of solidifying material discussed in class.
Covered interested, practical and very helpful set of topics and tools. Gave a good idea about to value the environment

The readings are very comprehensive, the professor has a ton of experience in the techniques (indeed, invented some of them), and students get to actually apply the techniques by conducting their own valuation. Being able to conduct a new valuation is definitely the highlight, as the hands-on work of empirically investigating the theory is great experience.
A good overview of the methods for valuing the environment from a professor who thinks and speaks very clearly.
Economic way of thinking pollution management issues
A real survey research by youself. Also the worst part...
The use of publications that were relevant and important gave a good sense for the evolution of the topic.
You get a general understanding of the different valuation techniques used.
The instructor broke down the concept very well, and explained them clearly, with ample examples. Great to learn from someone who has actually developed those techniques.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: The way the midterm was designed. It did not reflect our understanding of the course material nor valuation techniques.
Structure of lectures and project.
N/A

This course needs to have problem sets. The theories were great, but it would be much more valuable if we could try applying them. The instructor's handwriting is very illegible, which is frustrating when you're trying to write down equations.
A more thorough review of methodologies - functional forms, controls, etc.

In general, more work - more guided opportunity to understand the methods and ideas. Practicing a CV was great - but the guidance behind writing the paper and implementing was barely there - even in pursuing feedback, I didn't get a robust response. I would have appreciated the opportunity to find out what other students did, discuss the methods and readings with other students, peak into a more complete picture of the methods.More importantly, I would have liked to better understand what is happening currently with these valuation methods. How are academics, the government, NGOs implementing these ideas? How are they effecting policy? Most/all of the readings and examples were old, and focused on a narrow set of topics - would have been interesting to understand how these techniques are used with more issues, and how they might fit into broader social science/psychology survey techniques.Also, Professor M is often somewhat dismissive of student comments and questions - he sometimes doesn't really listen to what someone is saying, but makes assumptions about what that person is saying and replies based on on the assumption as opposed to what the person is trying to communicate.
Needs to be taught over multiple days, one day for 3 hours is brutal
Better instrucion and guideline to contents of every classes.

There were no guiding books (texts, chapters) or documents (slides, summaries). All that was provided was a syllabus and the publications. It would have been nice to have some sort of guiding document that put all of the methodologies presented into context in order to understand how I might be ready to use these in future in a real sense, rather than occasional asides in lectures and feeling uncertain how these might be useful to me if I do not pursue further studies in economics.
The readings are a big outdated. Some of them date back more than 10 years and the there is more recent information out there.
More consistent practice assignments would be helpful for making sure that all students understand the concepts.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: Both were responsive. The instructor had limited office hours and was in high demand. The TA was always responsive and available by email and in person.
Would be nice if the instructor had more office hours. He is in high demand and it's a fight to get time with him, but when you do he is helpful. TA was good with availability and helpful.
very good
I contacted the TA mainly and she was very helpful and organized.
N/A
They were both very helpful.
Both the professor and TA were available to answer questions as needed, and did so helpfully.

Not great. Professor M and Laura are very nice but not terribly available. Only one office hour per week from the TA for a large class wasn't really enough. Professor M's office hours are always completely swamped, and he doesn't use a sign in sheet. Laura was very responsive to email, however, and I really appreciated that.
TA is really nice.

I had more interaction with the TA, who held weekly sessions and was FANTASTIC. The TA proceeded very linearly through the material and summarized very clearly aspects of the different methodologies and what the key takeaways are about each one. She was enthusiastic, and her grasp and presentation were confidence-inspiring.
TA and professor were available and provided good support!
Both the instructor and TA were greatly helpful. TA prepared weekly sections that were very helpful for understanding what was covered in the lecture.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: important
I wish it taught me more applicable skills and quantifiable methods but it didn't.
I audited the course. Felt it would be good to have an understanding of the economics of the environment and how we can use economics tools to manage the environment
This course is an important part of the environmental economics focus and thus is essential to my overall program.
Maybe tell a little more on how to analysis the result with software and in the paper.
This course is an interest of mine that relates to how my research is applied but is not directly part of what I research.
Valuing the environment is useful if interested in putting some figures in nature, widely use for conservation programs and payment for environmental services, REDD, etc.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: To learn more about ecosystem services.
important for my research
To gain more quantitative skills in methods of determining an economic value for aspects of the environment.
Personal interest
To better understand the range of economic techniques for valuing the environment.
It's related to my own research.
I wanted to get a sense for how research like mine may be applied.
I am interested in ES, so getting the right incentives involves having a greater environmental economic understanding, where valuing the environment techniques are highly used.
Wanted a concrete understanding of environmental valuation techniques.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: Not quite, though it may fit the needs of other students better. I would have liked to learn about urban ecosystem services in a practical way and maybe get some experience valuing urban ecosystem services.
yes
No.
Yes
Yes, but with more applied work, it could have been better.
Yes
Not really - see complaints above. Would have liked a more robust academic experience.
The course turned to be not the same as my expectation, quite different from my research and previous knowledge, but also helpful, I think.
Not fully, I was looking for a more rigorous course on the quantitative aspect, and the course is more qualitative. The course doesn't not provide stronger skills for the non-economist
yes

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: No, but those interested in a survey of valuation techniques might be more fulfilled.
Yes.
Not quite. There was a lot of overlap with Gillingham's course.
yes
Not at all.
Yes
Would have gotten more out of it if the course load was a little heavier.
Yes
Not really - please see complaints above.

I expected to have a better sense of what I might be directly and personally able to do as a forest manager or researcher regarding valuation, but perhaps that is too much to expect after just one course.
I got an overall understanding of the different techniques, but I would need further guidance to actually applied them in a concrete case.
yes

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: N/A

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Ask questions in class specifically related to what you are interested in. Professor Mendelsohn is happy to answer these questions, even though he doesn't specifically raise these topics in class.
Go in to office hours and discussion.
read the paper before the class
Don't - it's a waste of time.

I think it makes more sense to do the readings after the class rather than before the class. He goes through the topics in class and the readings will be much easier to comprehend after having some background information.
Have some understanding of economics; do the readings
Make sure you have a background understanding of economic theory, also when that is fresh if you have been out of school a few years.

Get the CV paper out of the way as soon as possible. Be prepared to take a very active role (seeking out the professor, finding more readings) to get a robust education on the topic - otherwise, it's pretty easy to glide through the course.
Keep good notes, or youwill get lost when reviewing.
For a general understanding of the different valuing techniques, its worth taking the class.
